name: Hib/MenC vaccine
description: Find out about the Hib/MenC vaccine, including what it's for, who should have it and how to get it.

hasPart.description: The Hib/Men C vaccine is given to babies when they’re 1 year old to protect them against Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and meningitis C.

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine
hasPart.text: What it's for

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine
hasPart.text: Who it's for

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine
hasPart.text: Contraindications

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine
hasPart.text: How to get it

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine
hasPart.text: Side effects
The Hib/MenC vaccine helps prevent Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and meningitis C, which are serious, life-threatening bacterial infections.
1-year-old babies (if they were born on or before 30 June 2024) are given the Hib/MenC vaccine as part of the NHS vaccination schedule.
Most children can have the Hib/MenC vaccine. They only need to avoid it if they've had a reaction to an ingredient in it or to the 6-in-1 vaccine.
Your GP surgery will usually contact you to arrange your child's Hib/MenC vaccination. Speak to your GP surgery if you've not been contacted.
Common side effects of the Hib/MenC vaccine include pain and swelling where the injection is given, a slightly high temperature and feeling irritable.

hasPart.description: The Hib/MenC vaccine helps prevent Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and meningitis C, which are serious, life-threatening bacterial infections.

hasPart.text:
The Hib/MenC vaccine helps prevent Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and the type of meningitis caused by group C bacteria.

These infections can be serious and life-threatening.

The Hib/MenC vaccine is given to 1-year-old babies (if they were born on or before 30 June 2024) after they've had 3 doses of the 6-in-1 vaccine, which also protects against Hib.

hasPart.headline: What the Hib/MenC vaccine is for

hasPart.description: 1-year-old babies (if they were born on or before 30 June 2024) are given the Hib/MenC vaccine as part of the NHS vaccination schedule.

hasPart.text:
The Hib/MenC vaccine is given to babies when they're 1 year old (if they were born on or before 30 June 2024) as part of the NHS vaccination schedule.

If your child has missed their Hib/MenC vaccine, contact their GP surgery.

It's best to have the Hib/MenC vaccine on time, but your child can still have it up to the age of 10 if they've had all 3 doses of the 6-in-1 vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Who should have the Hib/MenC vaccine

hasPart.description: Most children can have the Hib/MenC vaccine. They only need to avoid it if they've had a reaction to an ingredient in it or to the 6-in-1 vaccine.

hasPart.text:
Most babies and young children can have the Hib/MenC vaccine.

The only reasons they cannot have the vaccine are if either:

  • they had a serious allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) to a dose of the 6-in-1 vaccine
  • they've had a serious allergic reaction to an ingredient used in the Hib/MenC vaccine

hasPart.headline: Information
hasPart.text:
Getting vaccinated if you're unwell

Your child can have the Hib/MenC vaccine if they're unwell but do not have a high temperature.

If they have a high temperature, wait until they're feeling better before taking them to have the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Who cannot have the Hib/MenC vaccine

hasPart.description: You can check the ingredients in the Hib/MenC vaccine by asking to see the patient leaflet or searching for it online.

hasPart.text:
There is 1 type of Hib/MenC vaccine used in the UK. You can check the ingredients in the patient leaflet:

Menitorix patient information leaflet (Electronic Medicines Compendium website; PDF only, 239KB)

hasPart.headline: Hib/MenC vaccine ingredients

hasPart.description: Your GP surgery will usually contact you to arrange your child's Hib/MenC vaccination. Speak to your GP surgery if you've not been contacted.

hasPart.text:
Your GP surgery will usually contact you about your child's Hib/MenC vaccination. This may be by letter, text, phone call or email.

It's best if your child has the Hib/MenC vaccine on time, but they can still have it up to the age of 10.

hasPart.headline: Speak to your GP surgery if:
hasPart.text:
• you've not been contacted to get your child's Hib/MenC vaccine
  • your child has missed their Hib/MenC vaccination, or you're not sure if they've been vaccinated
  • your child is unwell – they may need to wait until they're feeling better before having the vaccine
  • you need to change a vaccination appointment

Your GP surgery can book or rearrange an appointment.

hasPart.headline: How to get the Hib/MenC vaccine

hasPart.description: The Hib/MenC vaccine is given as an injection into the arm or thigh. It can be given at the same time as other vaccines.

hasPart.text:
The Hib/MenC vaccine is given as an injection into the upper arm or thigh.

Only 1 dose is needed to boost protection against Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and help protect against meningitis C.

Children are also given a vaccine when they're 13 or 14 years old (school year 9 or 10) to boost protection against meningitis C.

hasPart.headline: Information
hasPart.text:
Having the Hib/MenC vaccine at the same time as other vaccines

The Hib/MenC vaccine can be given at the same time as other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal and MMR vaccines.

hasPart.headline: How the Hib/MenC vaccine is given

hasPart.description: Common side effects of the Hib/MenC vaccine include pain and swelling where the injection is given, a slightly high temperature and feeling irritable.

hasPart.text:
Most side effects of the Hib/MenC vaccine are mild and do not last long.

Common side effects of the vaccine include:

  • pain and swelling where the injection was given
  • a slightly high temperature
  • feeling irritable

More serious side effects such as a severe allergic reaction are very rare. The person who vaccinates your child will be trained to deal with allergic reactions and treat them immediately.

The vaccine does not contain live bacteria, so there's no risk of getting the infections from the vaccine.

hasPart.headline: Side effects of the Hib/MenC vaccine

mainEntityOfPage.text: The Hib/MenC vaccine is given to babies when they're 1 year old to protect them against Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) and meningitis C.
mainEntityOfPage.name: lead paragraph
Callout
mainEntityOfPage.text:
Changes to Hib/MenC vaccination

Babies who are born on or after 1 July 2024 will not get the Hib/MenC vaccine.

They will get a new 4th dose of the 6-in-1 vaccine when they are 18 months old instead. You'll be contacted when your child is due for this vaccine.

Find out more about vaccinations for children aged 18 months (GOV.UK).

hasPart.name: Callout
hasPart.text:
Changes to Hib/MenC vaccination

Babies who are born on or after 1 July 2024 will not get the Hib/MenC vaccine.

They will get a new 4th dose of the 6-in-1 vaccine when they are 18 months old instead. You'll be contacted when your child is due for this vaccine.

Find out more about vaccinations for children aged 18 months (GOV.UK).

mainEntityOfPage.name: section heading

mainEntityOfPage.text:
Most side effects of the Hib/MenC vaccine are mild and do not last long.

Common side effects of the vaccine include:

  • pain and swelling where the injection was given
  • a slightly high temperature
  • feeling irritable

More serious side effects such as a severe allergic reaction are very rare. The person who vaccinates your child will be trained to deal with allergic reactions and treat them immediately.

The vaccine does not contain live bacteria, so there's no risk of getting the infections from the vaccine.
